title: woman too fat ride pony
story: NewsWoman too fat to ride her pony after scoffing cheese and Malibu and cokesPaige Matthews, , was told by her vet that her pony had a bad back thanks to her weight gain - so she shed the poundsShareCommentsByLisa HutchinsonReporter:,  FEB NewsPaige was warned that her ponys bad back was down to her weight gain "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A woman who was told she was too fat to ride her pony after gaining weight has shed the pounds and dropped two dress sizes in just three months.Paige Matthews was devastated when a vet told her that she was the cause of her beloved ponys bad back and decided she needed to do something about it. Paige, , had enjoyed a diet of fried food, as well as scoffing cheese and chocolate and drinking Malibu and cokes and found the scales had soon crept up to st lb.That meant at ft in she was overweight and Dream, her pony, was getting the brunt, reports the Chronicle Live .And when Paige was told the truth by the animal medic, it really hit home.   Now the -year-old has set herself the task of losing three stones so Dream can be ridden in years to come. And she’s already lost nearly two stone in just three months after joining Slimming World in November. “It was in the summer last year that I was told by the vet that Dream needed a smaller rider or retire, said Paige, of Stanley, County Durham. I was basically too fat to ride my pony.   The vet said because she was carrying my extra weight, and the fact she is  years old, it was probably contributing to her bad back. Dream was given steroid injections and lots of love from Paige. But it was a lighter rider she needed most. “I got Dream when I was  years old, we have such a special bond. She’s my best friend and we do everything together, she added. We have an unbelievable bond, She follows me like a dog, she trusts me.   “I would be heartbrokenI couldn’t ride her again. We’ve been together for  years and I just love her.” Paige joined Slimming World in November and changed her eating habits and started cooking the healthy way. And she’s dropped from a dress size  to a size . Paige, who is studying a degree in children and young people at Newcastle College, said: “I haven’t ridden Dream since October and I said I would start riding her when I lost two stones.   I’m nearly there now and I can’t wait to get back on her. “My goal is to lose three stone and get down to nine-and-a-half stone. I am doing this for the both of us. “We are inseparable so she has given me the incentive.” Paige was given Dream on her th birthday and her pet became her best friend.   “I was cooking everything in oil and buying shop ready-made sauces,” added Paige. “I was eating cheese and chocolate, I have a big sweet tooth. Then at the weekends I was drinking up to  Malibu and cokes. Now that has all stopped. I still eat everything I like but I cook the Slimming World recipes. I still eat my favourite things, but just the healthy way. I still have cheese but less of it and chocolate is in small sizes and just for a treat. I only have a drink on special occasions now and it will be with diet coke.”

title: curran an injury worry for dundee ahead of hibs clash on friday
story: Craig Curran is Dundee’s major fitness doubt for their Friday night clash with Hibs at Dens Park.The former Dundee United and Ross County striker played at Livingston last weekend but has been nursing a stomach problem since the draw with Kilmarnock a fortnight ago.He hardly trained last week and has been missing again over the past few days.“Craig is very sore, he didn’t train all last week because of a stomach thing,” said boss Jim McIntyre.“He’s going to require a few days to get over it.”If it’s a case of wait and see with Curran, Jim is confident both Andrew Nelson and Andreas Hadenius will make it.Nelson had to come off after netting the equaliser at Livi when he aggrevated ankle and calf problems as he celebrated his goal.And Swede Hadenius was replaced early in the second half at the weekend after picking up a knock.Both, though, have responded to treatment and are expected to be fit for Friday.With four goals since his arrival from Sunderland last month, -year-old Nelson is the man of the moment at Dens.While the manager stresses the young attacker remains a work in progress, he’s been delighted with his performances so far.“Nelson is a goalscorer and I thought his finish at the weekend was excellent,” Jim added.“It looked ashe was stretching but he’s managed to generate it into the corner.“As I’ve said before, he is raw. He still needs a lot of work, working with a partner and when to link and stuff but I’m delighted with his goals contribution so far.”

title: dundee boss mcintyre ready to cross swords with new hibs gaffer heckingbottom
story: Jim McIntyre and Paul Heckingbottom will cross swords for the first time in their managerial careers when Dundee and Hibs clash at Dens tonight.However, while Jim admits to knowing little of his opposite number, his knowledge of the team he’ll be putting out means he’s not expecting too many tactical surprises.Hibs appointed Heckingbottom as the successor to Neil Lennon last week and he kicked off his time in Scotland with an Easter Road win over Hamilton Accies.While, in time, the Dee boss knows his opposite number will put his own stamp on the Hibees, right now he’s not expecting too many drastic tactical changes from the way they lined up under Lennon.“I don’t know him but he got off to a good start and Hibs have good players. It’s going to be a tough game,” said Jim.“He’s got good options as well, you need to be able to handle that.“We know what players he’s got to work with and we know their strengths and weaknesses like we do most of the other squads in the league. It’s about making sure yours are better than theirs on the night, that’s how it is in football.“We are back at home in front of the cameras and want to put on a good performance.”Dundee go into the game boosted by last week’s vital win at Livingston that hauled them out of the bottom two in the top flight for the first time since late August.Again, though, the manager is stressing it’s where the team are at the end of the season that counts.“We could be back down there come Saturdaywe don’t keep it going.“Livingston is gone now and now it’s all about this one.”

title: family pays tribute to dundee guitarist kenny whose music took him all over the world
story: The family of a popular Dundee musician have led tributes to the talented guitarist following his death at the age of .Kenny Day died last weekend having spent the last years of his le living with dementia.A well-known figure on the Dundee music scene, Kenny, from Lochee, played in bands such as The Bad Pennies, Ringer and Sanjo during the s and s.His touring career took him across Scotland and the world where he performed in Germany and New York.Kenny’s son, Kenneth Day Jr, said: “It didn’t matter what it was – everything was a joke to my dad.“I remember his car broke down one night in Germany and he managed to fix the fan belt with women’s tights which were in the car.“A few months later he was still driving around with the tights connected to the fan belt.“He liked the women too. He had all the ladies around him. Even in the care home, he was a charmer.”His daughter, Jackie, , from Fintry, said: “I want people to know how talented he was – music was his le.“He first started out at about age four when he sang on stage with his sister Wilma but he first picked up a guitar at age  and I’m not surehe stole his older brother’s guitar.”Jackie said her father had a wide taste in music, although The Beatles were his favourite and his band Ringer would often cover songs by the Fab Four.Kenneth, , from Menzieshill, said he was inspired to take up guitar by his father.He said: “He would always ask me, ‘which Beatles song are we going to learn this week ’“I play in a band now and took it from my dad. People know my dad – after I put it on Facebook I’ve just had loads of comments with people saying that my dad was like a mentor to them.“Some musicians have been in touch to say my dad taught them how to play.”Kenny’s elder sister, Phyllis Duffin, , from Craigiebank, said his talents went beyond his musical knowledge, adding: “He had learnt six languages from French, Spanish, Urdu to Polish. He was very talented but had no common sense.“He loved going to Campbeltown in the west of Scotland to visit his cousins. I remember phoning through at one point and his cousin telling me he had been chasing their car in a Wombles suit!”Kenny, who was the youngest of four siblings, was diagnosed with dementia in his early s and entered a care home.Jackie said: “He would forget lyrics, it’s like he was fading away. It was a horrible thing to watch.“It was hard for him, he couldn’t drive anymore but he knew what was ahead. He developed a stammer and got frustrated.”Kenneth said: “Dad was a smart man so it was heartbreaking to see him getting ill.“The other week we were all sitting round him and he hadn’t spoken in over two years but then he began blethering and singing in German.“I told my sister that dad was talking and then he recognised Phyllis when she came in.“His music was playing in the hospital room and my sister turned down the stereo.“Dad said, ‘don’t do that again’ – it was braw!”

title: shoppers complain of dundee post office mess as refurbishment is postponed
story: A Broughty Ferry Post Office has had its refurbishment delayed despite complaints of it being littered with “mess”.The Gray Street branch was originally going to close from February  to March  to be given a makeover but residents have now been told the refurbishment has been postponed “indefinitely”.Christine Kenny, from Broughty Ferry, regularly uses the branch.She said: “The condition of the Post Office is a disgrace, with quite a bit of litter around.“There are bags of rubbish dumped in the front shop.”She added: “It was to be refurbished, but when I was in today the assistant mentioned it has been postponed.“The Post Office should have a say about its condition.“Even a brush, cloth or duster wouldn’t go amiss.”Ferry councillor Craig Duncan spoke of the store’s condition, saying: “The refurbishment has been deferred by the postmaster rather than the Post Office. In a way it’s disappointing but it helps in the short term because the Barnhill Post Office remains closed due to fire damage.”He added: “A lot of these matters are down to the postmaster rather than the Post Office to deal with.“I understand the purpose of the refurbishment is to bring these things up to spec and I welcome that and it will happen at some point. It’s a sizeable building and most of the floor space is not being used at the moment.”“We don’t have a timescale for the works to be done but I’ll find out more in the next two to three months.“As soon as I am aware, I will make that public.”In a statement, the Post Office thanked the Tele for bringing the state of the store to their attention and said the postmaster will be contacted regarding the concerns.Postal services at the Barnhill office on Nursery Road have been closed since a fire at the MS News shop on October .The fire caused almost £, worth of damage, closing the store “indefinitely”.The Gray Street shop was closed in January last year until July, so the store could be made more modern.After the last refurbishment, the store had four serving positions on a modern-screened counter, two open-plan positions and a serving point at the retail section.The opening hours also increased by  hours a week, to operate from am-.pm.

title: tom duthie deeiy sos then dundee boss jim mcintyre is the man to call
story: Rather understandably, no one has asked Jim McIntyrehe’s a fan of the hit BBC show DIY SOS.Perhaps we should, becausehe leads Dundee to safety this season he might just be able to lay claim to being the Scottish Premiership’s version of its presenter Nick Knowles.For those lucky enough to watch only football on the box, it’s the one where Knowles and a team of tradesmen step in to help families or groups with building projects they don’t have the knowhow or resources to complete on their own. To add to the drama, it’s done as a race against the clock.And McIntyre is gaining a growing reputation for doing the same with top-flight clubs here.Four-and-a-bit years ago he arrived at Ross County with the Highland outfit seemingly already doomed to relegation.By the end of that season he hadn’t just kept the Staggies up, he’d rebuilt them into a squad that would go on and win silverware in the shape of the  League Cup.After the Dark Blues’ weekend win at Livingston got them out of the bottom two for the first time since the end of August, thanks to goals from new handy men Andrew Nelson and Scott Wright, there are strong signs he can do the same at Dens Park.McIntyre’s reign as Dundee boss started in October when he received an SOS from owner Tim Keyes and managing director John Nelms.After a miserable start to the campaign, the Americans’ dream of cementing their team as a force in the Premiership and, eventually, taking the club to a new stadium looked in danger of crumbling around them.Confirmation of just how dire the need for an emergency rebuild came in his first game in charge when the roof fell in during a - defeat at Livi. It showed how flimsy the foundations of the team were as they collapsed under the weight of the home team’s excellence at set-pieces.Almost exactly four months on and after that second visit to the Tony Macaroni Arena under the new boss, the structure looks much more sound.And it’s all thanks to the kind of speedy reconstruction he undertook at County and of which Knowles and his team would be proud. For the team that ran out against Livi at the weekend bore no resemblance to the one McIntyre had to work with when he first headed there.Not one of the players in the starting XI in October were on from the start this time and of the  who were involved on that first day,  have left the club.Only Kenny Miller, Cammy Kerr and Elliott Parish remain and, of those three, veteran Miller was the sole participant in the vital - victory.For McIntyre, to bring about almost a complete change in such a short space of time has been a gamble, one that will only be confirmed as paying offhis team are still in the Premiership come the end of the season.It’s one, though, that represents his best chance of success and it is very much a case of so far so good.While Dundee under him remain a work in progress, the signs of improvement have been there for all to see.Since the end of the winter break there have been two wins, two draws and just one defeat in five league outings.By some margin that’s been the best run of form in the top flight so far this term.If it continues there is every reason to believe that target of building a team good enough for this level by the end of the season will have been achieved.Andthat is the case, fans will be hoping given more time, the manager will be able to set about putting together something even more impressive for next season and beyond.

title: Cyclists gather pollution data in Inverness
story: CLEAN air campaigners have strapped pollution sensors onto their bikes to expose the cityrsquos toxic air hotspots.The Highland Cycle Campaign is working with a student-led research project from Cambridge University to monitor air quality near roadways because of fears official figures are not capturing ldquodangerous levels of pollution.So far six members have used the pound monitors in ious areas including the A trunk road.And there are plans to extend its reach to the rest of the Highlands.Secretary Anne Thomas, who acts as local co-ordinator for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said the devices are showing where the most polluted areas are.She said: ldquoThe first maps show pollution levels on Academy Street and at the Longman roundabout as particularly high.And she claimed that the levels did seem, in some cases, to be breaching standards ldquowhich should have been met in .She added: ldquoIn reality there is no safe level of pollution which is responsible for thousands of premature deaths a year across Scotland.Mrs Thomas hopes the findings inspire more people to cycle as studies show car drivers spend longer in toxic air than walkers or cyclists on main roads.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Final page turned for Invernesss Christian bookshop
story: A CHRISTIAN bookshop in Inverness which has served the Highlands for nearly four decades will soon be closing.The CLCbook-shop in Castle Street provides literature from a Christian viewpoint to local churches and has been a resource centre for the wider community.CLC is a charity which started in Colchester in  and has been operating in Inverness for about  years.Prior to its move to Castle Street about eight years ago the shop was located in Church Street.Shop manager Pam Kerr said the closure decision follows a dropping off in customer footfall.ldquoItrsquos sad because as well as being a valuable resource centre for the Christian community it was a very popular place for people to come in for a coffee and to enjoy some fellowship, she said, adding that its resources will continue to be sold online.Miss Kerr, who is a member of the Inverness Christian Fellowship which meets at Merkinch Community Centre every Sunday, said that although the shop was closing an exact date would depend on how soon someone is found to take over the lease.ldquoCLC has been in Inverness for nearly  years and I have been the manager of the shop since it moved to Castle Street, she Business Improvement District previously said the closure was ldquounfortunate but hoped a new tenant would be found soon for a business that was ldquowell fitted out.This week signs outside the title: First phase of 32m refurbishment completed at Inverness school
story: THE first phase of a major refurbishment programme at an Inverness primary school has been completed.Two new classrooms have opened at Smithton Primary, much to the delight of principal teacher Lynne Macdonald who said the new facilities increased opportunities for its  children as well as staff.Pupils have also got a new a multiuse games area.ldquoItrsquos made a huge dference, she said.ldquoIt gives us a lot more space and just little things like having blackout blinds on sunny days and having all the children in seats at the same height really helps.The pound. million refurbishment project to address the schoolrsquos current and future capacity needs began last April.Once completed, it will see a total of five additional classrooms created along with two support needs rooms, a dedicated space for senior pupils and an extended gym hall.Local councillor Trish Robertson said it was excellent to see the project start to take shape.ldquoThe expansion was badly needed and having the extra space must be better for the children, she said. ldquoIrsquom really pleased itrsquos gone up so quickly.Iain MacDonald, special works manager for Morgan Sindall, which is carrying out the renovation work, said construction was currently on track for completion by September.ldquoThe most important thing for us has been not to interrupt the daily activity of the school, he said.ldquoBut another big thing is giving the kids a good experience of construction ndash therersquos a perception that construction is about the trades but therersquos so much more to get involved in.Miss Macdonald added: ldquoThe workers have been great. They always make sure they receive any deliveries before am which really helps and means the construction isnrsquot impacting the children. Thatrsquos the most important thing.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Highland Council investing extra in roads maintenance
story: Highland Council is hoping an additional pound. million for maintenance announced as part of this yearrsquos budget will make a ldquonoticeable dference across the region.The funding, approved as a priority area for the revenue budget, will be shared out across Highland with area committees able to decide how to prioritise it more locally.Chairman of the councilrsquos environment, development and infrastructure committee, Councillor Allan Henderson, said: ldquoWe have the most extensive network of roads in the UK and, added to this, we are faced with some of the most severe weather conditions in the Highlands.ldquoThe freeze-thaw conditions in particular cause immense damage to road surfaces and this is very evident in the past few weeks.ldquoRoad conditions are a high priority for local residents and this was very clear in our recent engagement with communities and local representatives.ldquoThe additional resource will, I hope, make a noticeable dference and can be allocated to the roads with the most urgent need of repairs, right across the Highlands.Area allocations based on road mileage and population are:Badenoch  Strathspey: pound, Caithness: pound,Inverness: pound, Lochaber: pound, Nairn: pound,Ross  Cromarty: pound,Isle of Skye: pound,Sutherland: pound,Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Inverness Airport travel figures on the rise
story: Inverness Airport has continued to have a rise in passengers with an increase of . per cent, up to , travellers, in .However, overall figures from Highlands and Islands Airports Ltd , show a minor drop of . per cent in passenger figures across the  airport network.In  ,,passengers use Hial airports, compared with ,, in , with Barra, Campbeltown, Dundee and Wick all having slight drops in passenger journeys.Sumburgh in Shetland had the biggest fall of . per cent, largely due to a change to helicopter operations in the oil and gas sector.Hial managing director Inglis Lyon said: ldquoThe overall figures illustrate the need for continued investment and support in regional airports that offer connectivity for the communities they serve.ldquoInverness Airport continues to grow and is playing an ever more important role in improving connectivity to and from the Highlands.Its international connections and regular flights to hub airports in Amsterdam, London and Dublin make it an attractive proposition for travellers.That growth could continue this year when BA starts its double daily flights between Inverness and Heathrow and KLM introduced three flights per day on its Amsterdam service for the summer season.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Inverness firm says Brexit is making customers cautious
story: UNCERTAINTY over the UKrsquos withdrawal from the European Union is causing people to delay home improvements according to an Inverness company.Cairngorm Windows has enjoyed its best start to a year in  years but managing director David Dowling says domestic customers are holding off finalising orders.ldquoPeople carrying out house improvements are approaching us but Brexit is delaying them from pressing the button he said.ldquoIn addition, our German fitted kitchen supplier have notied us of a . per cent import duty tax on all deliveries after March  in the absence of a deal going through.ldquoHowever, wersquove a record-breaking forward workbook thanks to the strong volume of orders from housebuilders while council contracts are at their highest level in  years.A pound, new computer operated cutting machine was fitted in January to drive forward Cairngormrsquos high-tech production process which saw a record , windows manufactured last year.The company aims to produce , windows this year and break the , barrier next year.Mr Dowling said housebuilders like Tulloch Homes, Springfield Homes, Compass and Scotframe had signicantly stepped up their forward orders while windows were being sold as far away as Swindon.Wersquove a strong domestic business where we supply and fit from fitted windows to fitted kitchens, he said.ldquoBut customers are currently telling us theyrsquore holding off the spend because of Brexit causing uncertainty to household budgets.ldquoWe hope that situation clears before too long.The company, which employs  people, installed a pound, automatic welder and corner cutter last year.It has been in business for  years.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Opinion divided on how to tackle Inverness gull menace
story: TIDY streets could be a more effective deterrent to Invernessrsquos seagull menace than culling, according to the RSPB.The suggestion comes in response to a call for a limited cull by city businessman Charlie Barbour.Mr Barbour, who owns city centre bars The White House and The Dog House as well as commercial property agency Barbour Commercial, suggests that destroying a small number of nesting pairs would make the centre of Inverness more attractive, safer and quieter.Describing the birds as ldquonoisy, dirty, aggressive and a blight on the city centre, Mr Barbour questions whether the Inverness Business Improvement Districtpolicy of removing eggs each year is enough to permanently reduce the gull population.ldquoWhilst a cull of such birds is not a universally popular decision, I just wonderthere is merit in destroying say three or four nesting pairs of seagulls each year, he writes.ldquoA reduction in seagull numbers would improve the city centre experience for visitors and that surely has to be a good thing However, a spokeswoman for conservation charity the RSPB said that lethal control should only ever be a last resort, used only where there is a proven problem and other alternatives have proven ineffective. Instead, local authorities, businesses and iniduals should tackle the problem by reducing the birdsrsquo food supply by cutting down the amount of edible litter and introducing gull-proof litter bins.Other non-lethal options include putting up physical barriers such as netting on roofs as a deterrent before the breeding season.ldquoWe believe that gull problems in an urban environment are best tackled by reducing the availability of food and nest sites. If the features that attract gulls remain, any `vacanciesrsquo created by controlling existing gulls will simply be filled by other gulls moving in, she said.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Roads not safe for city cyclists says Inverness campaigner
story: A LOT needs to be done to bring roads in Inverness up to a standard that makes them safe and easy for road users to navigate, a leading cycling campaigner has said.Brian MacKenzie, convener of the Highland Cycle Campaign, said: ldquoI cycle a lot and there is no doubt the roads in the town are in very poor condition.ldquoThe trunk roads, too, need attention.Championing the cause for better and safer routes for cyclists he said drivers also need to be aware of cyclists and give greater consideration to them.ldquoDrivers often criticise cyclists when they see them weaving along certain routes but often they are doing that simply to avoid potholes and are taking evasive action, he said.ldquoAt the Raigmore Interchange, on the ramp joining the A south from the A, there is a pothole which has been there for some time. It is now gathering water and there is a warning sign for traffic alerting them to flooding.ldquoThere are also two more long potholes which are much more dangerous for cyclists and motorists just as you enter the interchange off the northbound ramp, coming from the Beechwood direction of the A.ldquoThe seal between the interchange and the ramp has gone andyou are cycling along there on a dark night you canrsquot see it, so your wheel can get caught up in it. These are like tram lines and they could throw you off a bike and cause serious injury.ldquoEvery vehicle coming from the A has to go across these potholes as they enter the interchange as well and they have been like that for a considerable time.ldquoI am wondering when the trunk roads people are going to carry out these repairs.While Highland Council is responsible for the upkeep of most roads in Inverness and the surrounding towns and villages, Bear Scotland is responsible for trunk roads.A spokesman for the organisation told the Courier last week that major defects, including deeppotholes which could pose a danger to road users, are repaired within  days, with safety inspections of all roads under its care inspected on a weekly basis.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Sugars night set to be sweet for Highland Hospice
story: AN evening of fun, quality entertainment and good food has been promised by an Inverness man who is raising money for the Highland Hospice.Alastair Kennedy, communications director at Global Energy Group and chairman of Nigg Skills Academy, is calling on local businesses to try and help with his fundraising for this yearrsquos Strictly Inverness dancing competition.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom hoping that the business community will support this amazing cause as they have done in the past.Known to his friends as Sugar, Mr Kennedy will be hosting a dinner called Sugarrsquos Strictly Big Night at the Kingsmills Hotel in Inverness on April .The black tie tartan event will consist of live music from local band Torridon as well as an auction, quiz and a raffle, with all proceeds going to the hospice.Mr Kennedy is reaching out to the local business community to come along and support the event so he can raise as much money as possible.The director of Ross County Football Club is well known for his enjoyable hosting of hospitality at their home matches over the past  years, and thinks he has the the expertise and dry sense of humour to host another entertaining and enjoyable evening for all.As the oldest ever competitor in Strictly Inverness, Mr Kennedy was inspired to get involved in this yearrsquos event after sadly losing his mother to cancer in . She spent her final days in the hospice.ldquoTheir facilities and the care they provided for my mum was just so wonderful and considerate, he said.ldquoThey looked after her so well in her last days with us. I said at the time that I must, at some point in the future, do something to raise much-needed funds for the hospice, and with it being their th Strictly anniversary year, I just thought maybe now is the time.ldquoThere are lots of couples competing for the Strictly Inverness title and there is already great camaraderie being built up between us all.ldquoThis is not so much about winning, itrsquos more about raising money for this most worthy cause and everyone is working so hard not just in dance training, but in raising money by whatever means. I am hoping my business connections will assist me in being able to create a great night, but also raise as much money as possible for the hospice.Tables cost pound for  people and anyone interested should contact Mr Kennedy via Global Energy Group.Strictly Inverness also raises money for Inverness Ice Centre, which hosts the showdown from May .Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: boss mcinnes knew joe would go far
story: Aberdeen boss Derek McInnes is not surprised former Don Joe Shaughnessy has gone on to be a key player for St Johnstone and the Perth side’s captain.McInnes is keen to bring Shaughnessy back to Pittodrie for a second spell this summer.The -year-old centre-back left Aberdeen in summer , in the hunt for regular football despite the fact there was a new contract on offer from Aberdeen.The former Republic of Ireland Under- international has racked up more than  starts for St Johnstone and will today lead out the Saints against Aberdeen at McDiarmid Park.His contract expires at the end of the season.Aberdeen have held talks with Shaughnessy and his agent and also notied St Johnstone that they had made an offer to the defender for next season.St Johnstone have also offered a new contract in a bid to retain Shaughnessy.McInnes said: “Joe has done very well and the fact he is now the St Johnstone captain shows his qualities.“He was a brilliant player to work with when he was here. Joe has matured into their captain which is no surprise.”Aberdeen will today look to extend their winning run away from home to seven matches.In contrast, the Reds – five points behind second-placed Rangers – have secured just two points from the last possible  at Pittodrie.St Johnstone ended a slump in form last weekend when holding Rangers - at Ibrox.They had lost five straight games prior to that, although three of those were to Premiership leaders Celtic.McInnes said: “Our away form has been good and we maybe enjoy the spaces we get a bit more on the road.“I watched St Johnstone’s game against Rangers last week and they stopped the bleeding from the games against Celtic.“That can be tough when you play Celtic consecutively and they took a couple of sore ones.“St Johnstone are the type of team who can go on unbeaten runs eventhey have lost a few.“They managed to stop the rot with a draw and a clean sheet against Rangers.“It will be tough but we have to make sure it is tough for them.”Aberdeen have a depleted defence for the trip to Perth with centre-back Scott McKenna serving the final game of a three-match suspension.On-loan Watford centre-back Tommie Hoban is out for the season having sustained a cruciate ligament injury that will require surgery. Centre-back Mark Reynolds is on loan at Dundee United for the season.Right-back Shaleum Logan is sidelined for today and may require future surgery on an ankle problem.McInnes said: “We will need to make a decision that is best for Shaleum.”

title: bid chiefs vision gets msp seal of approval
story: An Aberdeen business chief has met a cabinet secretary to promote the importance of business improvement districts.Aberdeen Inspired represents more than  businesses who pay a levy which helps fund improvements across the city centre.The newly-formed Scottish City BIDs Group met Aileen Campbell MSP, the Cabinet Secretary for Communities and Local Government, this week.Business rates and a tourism levy were among the issues discussed during the meeting in Edinburgh.The meeting saw Allan Henderson, chairman of Aberdeen Inspired, acting as chair, and the body’s chief executive, Adrian Watson, as vice-chair.The Scottish City BIDs Group was established to progress the strategic objectives of the Business Improvement Districtsin cities across the country.Issues discussed included the effect off the current structure of business rates on firms and the potential of a tourism levy and how this may be implemented locally.Mr Watson, who is also vice-chair of the Scottish City BIDs Group, said: “We are grateful to the Cabinet Secretary for her input into the newly formed Scottish City BIDs Group.“In many ways Scotland is ahead in the placemaking agenda, but it was felt this position could be re-enforced with the city BIDs coming together to collectively look to influence policy-makers at a local national level.“Along with this there is the aim of sharing good practice, of which there is plenty, looking at the economy of scale in procuring goods and services and generally furthering the Scottish urban BID agenda.”Meanwhile, Roddy Smith, CEO of Essential Edinburgh, added: “It is so important the city BIDs have this voice.“When you consider the added value that my organisation, Aberdeen Inspired and the other larger BIDs have brought to our Scottish cities, this seems the logical step for us to collectively look at the strategic issues affecting our cities and looking at ways to make progress on them.”

title: dancing brings light and beauty amid the grief to ardfern
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe Nowby Laura MaxwellWithin This Dust is an interpretive dance performance inspired by the most horrying incident of our time: the   terror attacks.A packed Craignish Village Hall held host to the Dundee-based Shaper Caper performance on Wednesday February .Inspired by photographs of the   fallout, choreographer Thomas Small has created a performance that has been seen to bring tears due to its beauty and the tragedy of this story. First performed in , Within This Dust has gone on to be staged all over the UK and internationally, including at the   memorial and museum.Especially inspired by Richard Drew#s unforgettable photograph, The Falling Man, Within This Dust details the experience of witness, Lisa Hood, and victim, Vince Virr, of the   attacks.The witness finds herself surrounded in dust, made of crumpled paper, and begins a grieving process of hunting through the papers, finding meaning in the words, as someone tries to tidy around her. The second act features the victim joining the witness, creating a connection that will inevitably be broken, when finally, in the third act, the victim is alone, caught between a choice of the smoke and fire within the collapsing building or the  metre drop to freedom.It was a very poignant performance, tenderly expressing the horror of the incident, perhaps now weakened due to overindulgence. When the lights came up everyone stayed where they were, perhaps a little too stunned to move. Chatter was in whispers, for respect to people who could not hear them.As the narrator of the show captured and pieced together from coverage of the attacks said, the dust has not settled, and never will. The losses of the people in the planes and buildings is still felt, and the wider western world is still wary, still learning, still recovering.Within This Dust manages to depict the horror of that day beautully, and more importantly, delicately. No easy task for a grieving world.PIC:Craignish Village Hall was full. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood amongst the #dust#. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Lisa Hood. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood collecting dust. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood and Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustVince Virr facing the smoke, or the window. _aWithinThisDust

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe Ropework played host to this keenly contested local derby which was watched by a healthy crowd on Saturday February .And for the second time this season, Red Star and Campbeltown Pupils shared the points in a match both sides will feel they could have won.Both sides were struggling for fluency in the opening stages but Red Star settled first and grabbed the opening goal after  minutes. A long ball to the right hand side was met by Ryan Caskie who cut the ball back to Stuart McLean. The youngster took a touch before slotting past the Pupils# goalkeeper to give Star a - lead.Star continued to press and doubled their lead when Coll McCallum robbed the Pupils# defender on the edge of the box before cutting the ball across goal. The unfortunate Pupils# defender could only ert the ball into the empty net, with McLean waiting on a tap in. The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didn’t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. The equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when good play from Pupils down the right by Soudan saw him get a low cross in which was met by the on-rushing run of Ryan Deans and he finished well to level the score at -.This set up a frantic finish and both sides could have nicked it towards the end. Pupils went close with a headed effort which was clawed to safety while at the other end there was a goalmouth scramble which Star couldn’t convert and both sides had to settle for a draw in the end as referee Jimmy Litster blew for full time.Red Star were dealt a blow as it emerged that captain Aaron Moore suffered a dislocated shoulder. Hopefully this will not keep him out for too long.On Saturday February , Star have another important home game as they look to move off the bottom of the table when they take on Claremont AFC. The game will be played at the Ropework or Joint Campus G # weather permitting # with a pm kick off.

title: districts week 08
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsA poem a dayDo you like poetry  Or would you like to spend a little time listening to your own heart  Spring-time is marked out for reflection, new growth and the warmth of generosity in the Christian tradition. It is the time of Lent: the old Germanic word for spring-time. Our hearts are bidden to imitate the snow-drops: to come up from the darkness, raise themselves into the sunlight, and then fill the world with gladness.Parishioners from Ardrishaig, Christ Church, Lochgilphead and Glassary are joining together this Lent to read a poem a day through the  days of Lent and then Easter week. The poems have been chosen are in a beautul book, entitled The Heart’s Time, by Janet Morley. The poems come from across the English-speaking world, over the last four centuries. One poem is set for each day, accompanied by a short explanation, a reflection, and a brief suggestion for our own thinking.Parishoners will be reading the poems at home for those who wish it there will be meetings to share thoughts and inspiration at Ardrishaig Church during the weeks of Lent and at Christ Church on Sundays. Other meetings could be arranged, formally or informally.You can order the book from Fr Simon Mackenzie by emailing dr.lachlan@zen or calling  , or directly from Argyll Book Centre. Lent begins this year on Ash Wednesday March .Lynx reintroduced to Argyll and ButeFollowing on from an announcement that they were surveying Scotland in late , the Lynx UK Trust have identied three locations which could act as release sites for the medium-sized cats, including the Kintyre peninsula.Independent scientic research has shown that Scotland#s forest could sustain around  of the cats, which ecologists believe could help control the UK#s over-populated deer herds, leading to a regeneration of forest ecosystems that would benefit all of the UK#s native wildle.No lynx attack on a human has ever been recorded anywhere, though lynx reintroduction is a controversial issue with sheep farming unions concerned that the cats would decimate herds, though numerous independent studies make clear that sheep are an exceptionally rare target for lynx, even when the two live side by side.A public drop in consultation is scheduled for Tuesday March  from pm to pm in Tarbert village hall.E.ON donated to Arrochar roof insulationVehicles used by the Arrochar Mountain Rescue Team will benefit from being garaged at a more constant temperature this winter after the E.ON Energising Communities Fund paid for £, worth of insulation to be fitted at the rescue post.The volunteers making up the Arrochar Mountain Rescue Team provide search and rescue assistance throughout Strathclyde when requested by Police Scotland and can be called upon  hours a day,  days a year.  Working across all mountainous terrain and in any weather condition, they use three vehicles which are kept in the garage attached to the mountain rescue post in Arrochar which was built in .After mechanics identied condensation and corrosion as the cause of the vehicles’ increasingly frequent and expensive mechanical and electrical problems, heating was installed at the garage last year to reduce their maintenance costs and improve their reliability. It was then realised that roof insulation was necessary to lower the cost of the heating.Douglas Philp, team secretary for Arrochar Mountain Rescue, said: #As a charity, we’re totally dependent on donations, grants and volunteers. Fundraising can be a real challenge for the team, particularly as it comes on top of our primaryof providing a mountain rescue service.#PIC:Lynx cats could be reintroduced to the Kintyre peninsula. no_adistricts

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayrshire hospice marks 30th birthday

The work of the Ayrshire Hospice, irreplaceable since February , has formed part of the region’s fabric over three decades. But at pound, per day to fund bosses admit they owe their biggest debt to the public. Reflecting on the landmark birthday, chief executive Mandy Yule said: “Our message to the wonderful people of Ayrshire is ‘thank you’. “We wouldn’t be able to deliver the level of care we doit wasn’t for their support. “We have an incredible group of volunteers and fundraisers across Ayrshire, some of whom have given their time for over  years, and without the fundraising efforts the hospice wouldn’t be here.” Since opening its doors on Racecourse Road the base has become a centre of care, comfort, compassion and dignity to more than , patients.  But its true origins go back even further to a group of hard-working volunteers who set up their own trust in . Their goal was to raise the necessary funds to open a hospice in Ayrshire. After as initial target of pound, was met within  months the next task of finding a suitable location threw up Racecourse Road. Building work began in  and, with it, the hospice service was launched with the appointment of two home care nurses. From its earliest days fundraising has served the heart of the hospice. And it is that invaluable support that the hospice – which has almost  staff and volunteers – is recognising during its th year.   Mandy said: “Because of their efforts we have access to some of the best palliative care treatments available, allowing us to give our patients comfort and quality of le. “We have been privileged to give thousands of patients and their families the care and support they need, both at the hospice itself or wherever they have lived in Ayrshire, over the last  years and we take great pride in that”. To help mark the anniversary a special memory tree has been created giving the opportunity to leave reflections and memories of the hospice. Mandy said: “We never take the compassionate and continued support of the hospice by the people of Ayrshire for granted. “The memory tree gives people the chance to leave their own memories or thoughts about the hospice and be part of our celebration.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr NewsAyr

title: blooming marvellous ayr flower show
story: NewsBlooming marvellous as Ayr flower show sIt promises to be the biggest yet, with more classes and more entertainment.ShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB NewsTop team Chairman Tom Brown and Secretary Irene Yuill "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe third Ayr and District Flower Show will be back at Ayr Racecourse in August. It promises to be the biggest yet, with more classes and more entertainment. It is being switched this year to a Friday and Saturday to avoid a clash with the Sunday market. Ticket prices will remain the same at just pound and under-s free, new secretary Irene Yuill revealed. The experienced administrator, now retired from Auchincruive College, has been drafted in to assist chairman Tom Brown and the committee of volunteers. The show will be staged on August  and . Secretary Irene revealed winners will not get a prize money cannot buy and added: “Adults will no longer get money for winning classes. Instead they will get a fine crystal keepsake. This will be engraved and presented for the best exhibit in each section.” New classes will be introduced for the first time this year including Handicrafts, Baking, Preserves and Walking Sticks. Lego Models and a Miniature Garden in a seed tray will be added to the junior section. All classes will be FREE to enter.   There will be a wide range of trade stands including some craft stalls. Ayr Racecourse will again run a Food Market in the Princess Suite. There will be Cookery and Floral Demonstrations. Irene added: “For the first time this year we will be joined by the Model Railway Club who will set up a display and musical entertainment will be on offer.” The organisers are looking for as many volunteers to help, including stewarding and unseen work in the background such as stage building and dismantling. Chairman Tom Brown said: “To run the show we rely on the good will of the many volunteers who give up their time. We must thank everyone who has helped make Ayr  District Flower Show the success it has been over the last two years and hope we can count on their support again this year. “It is a great family day out with something for everyone to enjoy.” *Enlist your help by mailing ayranddistrictflowershow@gmail or  .

title: malawi partners set top tour
story: NewsMalawi partners get set for top tour of AyrshireErnest Chirwa and Francis Juma from Bandawe All Girls Secondary School and Bandawe Primary School will embark on a tour of Ayrshire from March  - .ShareByAbi Smillie:,  FEB NewsFrancis Juma with Bill Duncan, Elder from Alloway Parish Church "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAlloway Parish Church are gearing up to welcome partnering head teachers from across the globe next month. Following the success of the Alloway Malawi Mission , the church, in partnership with Alloway and Doonfoot Primary Schools have invited two head teachers from their partner schools in northern Malawi to visit Ayrshire in March. Ernest Chirwa and Francis Juma from Bandawe All Girls Secondary School and Bandawe Primary School will embark on a tour of Ayrshire from March  - . A full itinerary has been organised including working with and observing the teachers and head teachers across local schools including Belmont Academy and Wellington School. Ernest Chirwa and Francis Juma will attend worship at Alloway Parish Church on both Sundays, and will join families at Messy Church on March . And a fun-filled community “Scottish Night” with ceilidh dancing, entertainment and a quiz will be held in the church halls on Saturday, March  from . – pm, to really make the visitors welcome. Alloway and Doonfoot pupils are very excited to meet the head teachers and to learn more about their friends from Malawi. Mr Juma and Mr Chirwa will also be able to attend the wonderful Pop UK recording, with concerts set to be held in the church on March . title: scots skating star set follow
story: NewsScots skating star set to follow Dancing on Ice heroes Torvill and DeanPrestwick lad Lewis Gibson is being touted as the next big thing in British ice dance and has his sights set on the next Winter Olympics in Beijing.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA skating star who caught the ice bug while watching telly is being primed for a shot at the Olympics. title: taking look back ayr high
story: NewsTaking a look back at Ayr High Streets changing styleBack in , the Auld Toun was saying farewell to J Thomson  Son – a business which had been founded in the s.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  FEB NewsHats fill a window at J Thomson  Son, gents’ outfitters "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs Ayr High Street faces up to an uncertain future, it’s worth looking back on an earlier break with the past, writes Edwin Lawrence. Back in , the Auld Toun was saying farewell to J Thomson  Son – a business which had been founded in the s. The shop was taken over to make way for the giant Buttermarket development that saw British Home Stores move in. Ironically, BHS has now also gone, and that part of the town must again try to re-invent itself. Joan Kirk, , provides us with a link back to Thomsons’ wonderful shop.  For in  she was Mrs Thomson, and husband Gilbert was the third generation in his family to run the business. Mrs Kirk recalls: “Other old-established clothing businesses had closed by then, but Gilbert kept profit margins low to stay competitive. “However, BHS made him an offer he couldn’t refuse. “It was perhaps a blessing in disguise, as I got to spend time with Gilbert before he died in , aged .”  Mrs Kirk later remarried but has been widowed for a second time. The young Joan had come to Ayr in  from Lochmaben, Dumfriesshire, to train as a nurse. She later met dashing young shop owner Gilbert, and the pair were married, going on to have a son and daughter. Hats were a signicant part of the Thomson business when Gilbert’s grandfather opened the shop in Victorian times. A large top hat is clearly visible above the front door in the old photo.

title: volunteers bid breathe new life
story: NewsVolunteers bid to breathe new le into Ayr town centre with arts hubThe team behind the move say they will bring fresh ideas and creation to the towns bottom end.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA bid to breathe new le into Ayr’s emptying High Street will be staged by hard working volunteers. The group insist a “cultural hub” can spark much needed footfall at the town’s tired bottom end. And they hope a plan to rent the former clothing store, Millets, will aid their cause. FreshAyr, the team behind the project, are not new to opening ‘pop-up’ spaces in the town. But boss Robert Singer, , insists: “We believe this next phase is potentially our most important. “Ayr has lost its place as a market town and tourist destination. “Long gone are the factories, fisheries and agricultural markets of the past – even retail is failing. “So there is a serious pressing need to rethink the way people engage with High Streets. “Our project will focus on the arts and use it as a force for regeneration.” The team have won a three month ‘proof of cause’ deal which, they hope, will lead in turn to later funding.   Robert explained: “We have a five year project in mind with this unit ideally being our permanent base. “Until now, we have operated around the town on a pop-up basis but that is never ideal. “We’d like this as our home.” The ‘BREAD arts lab’ will launch next month and run in conjunction with the project’s bakehouse, which is set to operate from Cathcart Street. Robert said: “We want people to engage with the process...to come in and literally see bread being made before their eyes before taking it home. “At our High Street base we will stage exhibitions, performances, music and art. “We want this to be a centre for everything creative.” •What is your view  Send us your opinion by email on news@ayrshirepost or give us a call on  .Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr News

title: watch-virtual-tour-of-new-jedburgh-campus-ahead-of-public-open-day
story: BORDERERS are being invited to see howJedburghs new school is progressing.Work began on the pound million intergenerational campus last summer.And on Thursday, March  an open day will be held at the site.Leader of Scottish Borders Council Shona Haslam said: ldquoThere is real excitement building as we approach one year until the new Jedburgh campus opens.ldquoEngagement with the people of Jedburgh has been key to this project since its inception, and is continuing with the upcoming Open Doors Day event and the information session taking place for community groups, alongside the ongoing consultation to provide a name for the new campus.ldquoWe are determined to continue to improve our school estate to ensure it is fit for purpose for our young people, staff and local communities.The new campus at Hartrigge Park will replace Jedburgh Grammar, Howdenburn and Parkside primary schools.And it will have provision for nursery, primary and secondary school children while community facilities will include a multi-use games area, G hockey pitch, G sports pitch, running track, external changing pavilion and rural skills area.Councillor Carol Hamilton, SBCrsquos executive member for children and young people, said: ldquoI would encourage the local community to find out more and get involved in the events being held in the coming weeks and months.ldquoFor those who cannot make the Open Doors Day, we have provided a virtual tour of the exterior of the building on social media, and will be adding another of the inside of the building in the coming weeks.ldquoExcellent progress is being made with construction of the campus, which means it remains on course to open to Jedburghrsquos young people and the community in spring .Bruce Dickson, of contractors BAM Construction, added: ldquoAs members of BuildUK, we fully support Open Doors Day which is designed to change the public perception of the construction industry and what we do.ldquoJedburgh Campus is title: hey-big-spender-charity-begins-at-gala-opera
story: THEY often say Charity begins at home.Well for one week it will begin fairly close to home... at Gala Opera.Between Monday, March  and Saturday, March , Galashiels Amateur Operatic Society present the all-singing, all-dancing Sweet Charity at the Volunteer Hall.Once again Jeff Thomson, who spends his working days as Principal Teacher of Expressive Arts at Earlston High School, is at the helm as Producer Musical Director.Jeff is well known locally for his productions and, while Sweet Charity may not be as high-profile as some of his recent offerings, his reputation goes before him.And the massive stage hit of the s has been brought bang up to date, providing plenty of laughter and a few tears for audiences throughout the March run.Jeff brings all his expertise and professionalism to bear to modernise Sweet Charity.Working alongside Jeff is Marie McCullough, professional performer and co-founder of Creative Stage performing arts school based in Selkirk, who has the unenviable task of choreographing some of the shows most iconic dance numbers, including Big Spender, Rhythm of Le and Rich Manrsquos Frug.Together Jeff and Marie have brought some of Gala Operarsquos most successful productions to the stage in the Volunteer Hall in recent years.And Sweet Charity is no dferent.Carla McColgan takes on the role of Charity, ably supported by a large principal cast and chorus.Evelyn Watson from Gala Opera told us: "Donrsquot know the show  Donrsquot make that a reason not to go along."You will laugh, you will cry, you will tap along to the dance numbers, you will hear some of the best known songs in musical theatre and you will leave with a smile on your face."Sweet Charity opens on Monday, March  or six nights in the Volunteer Hall.Ticketsare available now at the box office in the Volunteer Hall

title: one-night-in-las-vegas-comes-to-galashiels
story: AFTER three years of sell-out stage shows, Scotlandrsquos top nine-piece showband, Spatz  Co will be launching their One Night in Las Vegas tour in Galashiels next month.The show offers a taste of the glitz and glamour from the famous entertainment capital of the world.And, with a uniquely designed stage set, there will be a sense of the theatrical giving audiences a truly showbiz experience.Roy Mac, producer, pianist and vocalist for Spatz  Co told us: ldquoLas Vegas is so much more than casinos, slot machines, neon lights and conveyor-belt weddings."Itrsquos also rightly known as the greatest entertainment city of the world a stage like no other, featuring some of the most iconic singers and musicians over the years."Our show celebrates the music of these performers in a way that we hope lts the spirit.Spatz  Co is a band made up of musicians who are all bandleaders in their own right.Between them, they play more than  instruments within their two-hour show.From swing to blues, soul to Latin, and jazz to pop, their repertoire includes songs made famous by stars such as Frank Sinatra, Elvis Presley, Barry Manilow, Chuck Berry, Paul Simon, Eric Clapton, and Michael Jackson.Galashiels fans will also be able to enjoy that popular Glen Miller big band sound.The range of music covered within the show is wide and deliberately ied, always leaving the audience wanting more.Having spent much of his childhood in the Scottish Borders, Roy added: ldquoWe are incredibly excited to debut this show in the Borders, and it will be the first time wersquove played at the Volunteer Hall in Galashiels."Spatz  Co play Galashiels on Saturday, March  from .pm.Tickets, priced at pound, are available online at www.liveborders.org.uk.Live Borders events manager Hamish Moir said: "We are very privileged to be hosting the debut show of the talented multi-instrumentalist band Spatz  Co."Their show is so ied, offering something for everyone, and all performed with the
