title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Saturday  Feb  : PM

story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Wick Francis Street Club placed in liquidation
story: WICKS Francis Street Club has been placed in liquidation, it was confirmed on Thursday.According to provisional liquidator Iain Fraser, a partner with FRP Advisory, the decision was made following a decline in membership, rising costs and unsustainable cash-flow problems. The club ndash founded in the s as a British Legion ndash has now closed and six staff have been made redundant.Mr Fraser said: "The Francis Street Club has been a landmark social, entertainment and sports venue in Caithness for nearly  years. Sadly, the club has been suffering severe financial problems and liquidation was the only option available to the committee."We are working closely with the relevant agencies, including the Redundancy Payments Office, to ensure the staff receive as much support as possible. We are now offering the assets of the business for sale, including the building, fixtures and fittings, and would urge interested parties to contact our Aberdeen office as soon as possible on   ."The Francis Street Club started was a long-established social, entertainment and sporting venue which attracted some well-known names through its doors, including former world snooker champion Stephen Hendry who staged an exhibition match there.It served as a social club and ran both football and darts teams, both well supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.The premises closed last month. At the time, a statement issued by the club said: "It was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , ."A note subsequently posted on the door read: "We have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course."Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: accessibility top of the agenda for northlink
story: Changes are being made by NorthLink Ferries to make their services more accessible to all.On board information workshops and the introduction of new website software are the latest efforts being made by the company to improve services for those with additional support needs.The ferry operator implemented its new Recite Me accessibility tool on its website, this month, to make it more suitable to folk#s needs. The new software — which can be used on desktops and mobile browsers — allows website visitors to customise what they see and hear, from changing the contrast settings, language, font size and more.In the UK, there are estimated to be . million people with a learning disability and . million people who have English as a second language. ‘Recite Me’ has the ability to translate the NorthLink Ferries website into more than  languages — including Scots Gaelic . It can also translate text-to-speech to help visually impaired users and focus screen areas for those with dyslexia.On Monday, February , teams on board MV Hamnavoe hosted an Access Panel Orkney session, where staff were provided with disability awareness training. During the two-hour session, staff were able to experience what it’s like to have a disability by wearing glasses that simulated blindness, used wheelchairs and crutches and had their hearing dampened.Carolyn Grfiths of Access Panel Orkney said: “The aim of our session was to let staff experience disabilities first-hand so they can empathise with passengers’ needs.#All of us running the training have a disability so we were able to provide first-hand examples of what accessible travel is like for us. We were delighted to be welcomed on board to provide this training and it’s great to see a company like Serco NorthLink Ferries take accessibility for passengers seriously.”The MV Hjaltland will also host a Making Connections workshop today, Friday, February . The workshop will look at how passengers navigate potential barriers when changing from one mode of transport to another. Making Connections brings disabled people together with transport operators to discuss, address and plan how travel connections can be made easier.Seumas Campbell, customer service director at NorthLink Ferries, said: “Catering for passengers with ying degrees of disability is an important part of our service provision. Whether they are using our website to book their journey, making a connection from other forms of public transport or coming on board one of our vessels, we believe that passengers should experience a service that caters to all their needs.“The new website software will allow visitors to customise what they see and hear and as more and more visitors from around the world choose NorthLink Ferries to travel to the Northern Isles, ‘Recite Me’ is a great tool to help them plan and book their journey.“Our workshops are also a great way in training our staff on how they can best help and understand passengers’ needs. We pride ourselves on having a great team that always provides the best service so it’s important that we’re constantly refreshing their training.”For more information on accessibility for passengers on NorthLink Ferries, you can visit www.northlinkferries copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: council issues kirkyards apology
story: Orkney Islands Council has made an official apology following public concern about the way the county#s kirkyards are being managed.Distraught families and dismayed public officials have spoken out in recent weeks, after a scheme to improve the safety of cemeteries triggered reports that headstones were being laid flat without relatives being notied.Last week, a council insider told The Orcadian that — in failing to contact families — the council was disregarding government guidelines on cemetery maintenance.“It says it’s good practice to inform the families and give them an opportunity to repair the memorial, and that’s just not being done at all,” the inside source said.The Orcadian also heard from Stewart Spence, whose father#s headstone had been laid down in the Sandwick kirkyard with no notication from the council. This was despite the fact that the name and address of the person they needed to contact — his mother Edna — was engraved on the memorial.#Vandals couldn#t have done a better job,# he said.Following this wave of public concern, OIC convener Harvey Johnston and chief executive Alistair Buchan have now released a statement apologising for the concern and upset that this project has caused.#Following a tragic accident involving a young child at a Glasgow cemetery, the Scottish Government asked councils to carry out detailed inspections in the interests of public safety,# they said.#We therefore engaged in the kirkyard safety programme for all the right reasons, but recognise that the process we have followed needs to be improved. It was never envisaged that the resulting work would leave kirkyards in the condition they are in. We are sorry about the concern and upset this has led to.#As a caring organisation, responsive to public concern, we will restore kirkyards to the condition people would expect. We will also consider how best to contact and discuss the remedial work required with those concerned. People’s safety is an important concern for us and we will continue to carry out headstone inspections. As at Warebeth , we will use blue pegs to mark stones identied as being unsafe and highlight these to local community representatives.#These stones will not be touched until we publicise the inspection results and give relatives the time they need to discuss with us any work they might wish to carry out themselves.#The statement also confirmed that further updates from the council will be provided further updates over the weeks ahead.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: german fleet salvage sites archaeology project results published online
story: With the centenary of the scuttling of the German High Seas Fleet in Scapa Flow fast approaching in June of this year, a fascinating insight into remains of aspects of the wrecks has now been published online.Historic Environment Scotland commissioned the Orkney Research Centre for Archaeology and SULA Diving to complete a full survey of the wrecks and debris remaining on the sea bed following the inter-war salvage operations.The seven remaining ships of the High Seas Fleet have seen Scapa Flow become one of the most well-known e sites in the World. Those wrecks are still the primary focus of recreational ers, but the remains of the vessels that were mostly recovered and removed from Scapa Flow have also been a recognised ing resource for many years.However, the exact extent and composition of these so-called salvage sites was unknown until this week, when the report of the second phase of work on these sites was published online.The overall aim of the Scapa Flow Salvage Sites Project was to determine what remains of the many vessels of the German High Seas Fleet that were salvaged in the years that followed their scuttling in June .Phase One, undertaken over the winter of  , involved a side scan sonar survey of the main anchorages and other areas thought to have been involved in the salvage process.In the second phase of this project, ers and remotely operated vehicles examined and recorded the remains in detail.The overall result is that the vast majority of salvage sites in Scapa Flow have been located and the remains at each site have been directly investigated and recorded.The full report is now available for public download through the Scapa Flow Historic Wreck website http:www.scapaflowwrecks projects salvage-sites-phase- Further details in The Orcadian on Thursday.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: in the footsteps of dr john rae
story: Next month will see a group of intrepid adventurers undertake a -mile mission in the Canadian Arctic, retracing the footsteps of one of Orkney#s most renowned, yet also overlooked, sons — Dr John Rae.The Arctic Return expedition will see a four-man team set off from Naujaat — also known as Repulse Bay — in late March, aiming to retrace the footsteps made by the surgeon, explorer and surveyor in .It was on that expedition that the explorer finally discovered an open channel to the east of King William Island in the high arctic. Known today as Rae Strait, it was the missing link in what would become the first navigable Northwest Passage.He also reported back on the ill-fated Franklin expedition, reported evidence of cannibalism — findings which were effectively rejected by the then establishment, and which led to Rae#s achievements being almost completely ignored.The modern-day team, who hope to raise further awareness of these achievements, will be led by Scottish-born and Canada-based expedition leader David Reid, with Scotland also represented by Broxburn-based former Royal Marine Richard Smith.The team will also include two Canadians — adventure film-maker Gerry Tutte and adventurer Frank Wolf.Over  years later and supported with modern-day kit from outdoor specialists Tiso, the explorers are hard at work preparing for the physical and mental challenge of hauling kg sledges for nine hours daily and for up to  consecutive days.Their route will cover undulating, windswept tundra, river valleys and sea ice during what can be the coldest time of year.The Arctic expedition will finish once the four explorers have finally reached Gjoa Haven on King William Island.Mr Smith said: #The Arctic Return expedition will be extremely tough but ultimately our aim is to raise awareness fo the exploits of John Rae and to help restore his rightful place as one of the greatest Scottish explorers in history. It is also our hope that this awareness will inspire the public to support fundraising efforts by the John Rae Society, to restore Rae#s birthplace at the Hall of Clestrain in Oprhir.The team have said any addition funds raised are to be used to produce a documentary film and book about the le and exploits of Rae, the expedition and the history communities, culture and wildle of the Arctic.The public will be able to track the team#s progress at their official website and through social media.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: mcarthur welcomes fuel poverty re think
story: Orkney’s MSP, Liam McArthur has welcomed Scottish Government plans to ensure that its Fuel Poverty Bill recognises the higher costs faced by those living in remote rural and island areas.During the stage one debate in Parliament yesterday, Wednesday, the Housing Minister, Kevin Stewart indicated that he would bring forward amendments to the bill to include an ‘uplt’ to the minimum income standard for rural and island communities. Mr McArthur believes this reflects a change in approach by the government, after months of campaigning by the Orkney MSP and a range of organisations involved in tackling fuel poverty across the Highlands and Islands.During his remarks, Mr McArthur pointed out that when it comes to fuel poverty, rural and island areas are disproportionately affected, with Orkney having the highest proportion of households in fuel poverty and extreme fuel poverty anywhere in Scotland.Commenting after the debate, Mr McArthur said: “Fuel poverty blights communities across Scotland, but there is no doubt that it has a disproportionate impact on rural and island areas. Until recently, however, the Scottish Government appeared unwilling to recognise this fact or indeed the higher costs faced by those living in our rural and island communities.“Over recent months, working with a range of organisations with a wealth of experience and expertise in tackling fuel poverty, I have made the case for the Minister, Kevin Stewart to think again.  It was a case that the Local Government Committee was also persuaded to support.“I am delighted, therefore, that the Minister has had a change of heart and committed to bring forward amendments to his bill at stage two that better reflect the specic nature of fuel poverty in places like Orkney.  I look forward to seeing the detail of those amendments and will work with Mr Stewart, and local stakeholders in Orkney, to make sure we get this right.“Given the impact fuel poverty can have, not just on people’s quality of le but their physical and mental health, this bill has the potential to make a real dference.  For that to happen, it must be both effective and ambitious in eradicating fuel poverty from communities across the country.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney art student to represent scotland
story: An Orkney College student will be one of  folk to represent Scotland at a special exhibition in Venice, Italy, this year.Jenny Sprenger has been selected to attend a professional development programme as part of the Scotland + Venice  exhibition during this year’s Biennale of Art in the city.Exhibition assistant Jenny will be given the opportunity to support Scotland’s presentation of new video work by Charlotte Prodger during the Biennale Arte  which runs from May to November.On being selected Jenny Sprenger said: “I am both thrilled and honoured to have been selected to be part of this opportunity, and I am looking forward to the chance to connect with other artists and see world-class contemporary art in the flesh.”Cove Park — an international artists residency centre based in Scotland — is spearheading the Scotland + Venice Professional Development Programme. This year, in addition to partnering with six Scottish art schools and colleges, the programme will benefit from new collaborations with the Scottish Contemporary Art Networkand Templar Arts and Leisure Centre , Argyll and Bute. story: Repairs to a faulty power cable, which links Orkney with mainland Scotland, have been completed and the cable has been put back into use.SSEN have said the cable was put back into service on Sunday evening and has been under normal operation since then.Prior to repairs being completed at Rackwick Bay, Hoy, a spokesman from the energy company said an investigation had shown the damage to be located at a section of the Pentland Firth East cable, near the shore at Rackwick.The spokesman said there was no impact to their customers as a result of the fault and contingency measures were put in place.SSEN also reported that, as part of its subsea cable inspection and replacement programme, a project to progress an end-to-end replacement of the Pentland Firth East distribution cable is at #an advanced stage of development#, with cable installation and commissioning due to take place in autumn next year.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Ambitious plan sets goals to end fuel poverty
story: PEOPLE across Ross-shire could benefit after the Scottish Government incorporated changes into its own draft legislation to ldquoend the scourge of fuel poverty.An earlier barrage of criticism claimed the Fuel Poverty Bill missed the target when it came to delivering for the ldquoworst affected areas.Fuel poverty is defined as when households spend  per cent or more of income on domestic fuel ndash reckoned to account for one in four homes in Scotland.The figure is understood to be signicantly higher across swathes of Ross-shire, hitting homes which are not on the gas grid and reliant on oil and low-income households.Minister for local government, housing and planning, Kevin Stewart, promised to include ldquoa rural, remote and island minimum income standard in poverty calculations as well as what he called ldquoa rural uplt.He was speaking at the first stage of a Holyrood debate of the Bill which aims to cut fuel-poor households to five per cent by  from the current national average of almost  per cent.The move was welcomed by rural housing associations and local councillors but Highlands Tory MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston vowed to maintain pressure on the government to deliver on what was promised.He said: "The minister announced that a new rural, remote and island minimum income standard will be included in their fuel poverty calculations alongside a rural uplt. We will be looking to strengthen the Bill as it progresses through the Scottish Parliament and ensuring that the Scottish Governmentrsquos pledges are met."Before Wednesdayrsquos debate Mr Stewart said: ldquoWithin this ground-breaking legislation, not only are we one of the few countries in the world to define fuel poverty, we are also setting a goal towards eradicating it.ldquoBy changing the definition of fuel poverty so itrsquos more closely aligned to relative income poverty and taking steps to ensure it works for remote rural and island communities, we are ensuring our support is focussed on those who need it most."He added: "In this day and age, it is unacceptable that any Scottish household should have to choose between having the heating on and cooking their dinner.Councillor Ian Cockburn, who represents the Wester Ross, Strathpeffer and Lochalsh welcomed the Bill as "something has to be done about fuel poverty" while arguing it is also time to rethink infrastructure like the national grid."It is ambitious but has to be tried to get fuel poverty down in rural areas. We are one of the most energy rich countries in the world so we should be able to get something done. Too many people take it as just being part of the landscape up here so we need to change that thinking as well to get people the assistance that they need."Scotland should not be in this state. But you have to look back, the National Grid was set up at the end of the war, the Highlands is considered off-grid despite supplying much of the rest of the country through hydro and wind power. It is time for a rethink."Calum Macaulay, chief executive of Invergordon-based Albyn Housing Society, said: ldquoWe welcome this development in the Scottish Governmentrsquos approach to addressing fuel poverty in rural areas. The push to include minimum income standards feels like a signicant step forwards. This is something that the Rural and Islands Housing Association Forum has been promoting for quite some time."This has included research undertaken with the support of Highlands and Islands Enterprise and others into minimum income standards in rural communities. The results of this highlighted the pressures of lower average household incomes and higher average fuel costs across the northern parts of Scotland."What do you think  Share your views by emailing newsdesk@spp-groupSaturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. For more details of these cookies and how to disable them, see our cookie policy.

title: Black Isle authors French connection helps ensure nothing is lost in translation
story: Vee Walkers Major Toms War, partly set in France during WWI, is now fittingly being translated into French for a new edition of the book.Such has been the response to the novel that the Black Isle author has already been on a book tour and visited France on the back of it. The annual Franco-Scottish Society Alexander Gray Fund Lecture in Inverness on Friday promises to be alight-hearted bilingual talk from Ms Walker and her "long-suffering" Parisian translator Richard Kausch.Major Tomrsquos War is a moving novel set in France during the First World War, in part in the grim lsquozones occupeacuteesrsquo of northern France.Its characters are real people ndash and both author and translator have had to enter the minds of the novelrsquos key protagonists.The novel is published in English by Kashi House in London and the French edition should follow late this year or early in .Veeand Richard will be touring four of the regional Franco-Scottish Societies of Scotland this month.The groups exist to foster French language and culture in Scotland and meet monthly for French conversation or a lecture.Those who come along are welcome to join or to attend as a non-member. They are suitable for Higher Advanced Higher French pupils and their teachers.Vee confesses that as a French-speaking author she has not madeher translatorsle any easier: "Most translators produce a translation and the author would not have a clue about whether or not it is representative or accurate."My first degree was in French and although I am not a native speaker, I have had an opinion on nuance and vocabulary right the way through."Richard is currently revising the French text a second time to address the changes requested by my English publishers for the First Edition. He has the patience of a saint and I donrsquot know what I would have done without him!"Wersquore both looking forward to meeting audiences in Aberdeen, Edinburgh, Glasgow and Inverness on our tour around Scotland very much."Vee and Richardrsquos final tour slot is in Inverness on Friday, February  at the Glen Mhor Hotel,  Ness Bank, Invernessat .pm.Thelecture is free and will be followed by a French meal atpm. title: Black Isle swimming pool is not yet sunk say supporters
story: DETERMINED campaigners fighting for a swimming pool dedicated to a fast-growing area of Ross-shire have succeeded in a last-ditch bid to keep the dream alive.The Ross-shire Journal last November told how activists behind a -year drive to establish a pool serving the Black Isle issued an appeal to a new generation to either take the plunge and get involved or see it wound up.The Black Isle Swimming Pool Foundationhas raised more than pound, and won planning approval for a new-build in Fortrose next to the existing leisure centre and secondary school.With anumber of BISPF stalwarts no longer able to continue driving the project, chairman Roy Sinclair appealed to Black Islers to grasp the nettle or wind up the foundation.A make-or-break project strategy meeting in Fortrose has seen a fresh commitment to push forward with a number of avenues to be investigated. These include:* A possible community buyout of the Black Isle Leisure Centre run by High Le Highland for Highland Council.* Appointing a business consultant to update the  business plan and probe funding applications.* Appoint a design team by competitive tender to revise the building plans and invite tenders.It was noted that the Black Isle remains a growing area with future housing and an expanding population.While a lottery bid for pound million towards the estimated poundm cost of the scheme failed back in , negotiations with the Scottish Land Fund via Highlands and Islands Enterprise to consider developing the project as a community enterprise company have continued.Mr Sinclair said: "A unanimous positive attitude was evident at the meeting which allows further progress to be made to develop this very important project for the benefit of folk on the Black Isle and beyond."A follow-up meeting is planned later this month.Whats your view  Email newsdesk@spp-groupSaturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Mystery oil tank artist adds a splash of colour to Invergordon
story: ITrsquoS a site steeped in local history and a lasting legacy to Invergordonrsquos nautical history.But the disused fuel tanks which stored the oil which powered some of the Royal Navyrsquos greatest warships during World War II has been a blight on the landscape of the Easter Ross port for generations.Recently, however, a graffiti artist has been hard at work beautying some of the relics, doing a lsquoBanksyrsquo with colourful images at the giant Seabank fuel tanks near the railway line, adding to lots of mural street art in the town already undertaken by the Invergordon Off The Wall group.Now the search is on to find the mystery painter who has already made a start on a canvas of over  massive tanks to choose from.Local woman Jacqueline Brown said she wasnrsquot sure exactly when the artwork was done: ldquoBut we would love to find out who is doing it.ldquoThe site really is out of bounds to the public but people go in and walk their dogs. I think I first saw the murals last year and they are quite stunning. Whoever is doing it is obviously very talented. Itrsquos a fascinating site. We know Invergordon became a naval town and was the base for the Home Fleet in World War I. These tanks were built for the supply of fuel to warships and they were in use until the mid-s.Mrs Brown said like many street artists, the person who carried out the work may wish to remain anonymous and even be fearful of prosecution.ldquoI just donrsquot know. But what they have done is quite beautul. I am sure we could find more projects for them in Invergordon including the town house which the community wants to take back into public ownership.A website documenting historical and derelict places in Scotland reveals the depot was built in conjunction with secret oil storage tanks a few miles away.It records the underground tanks were built to hold  million gallons of oil fuel and were built into a solid rock hill to protect it from bombs.On February ,  a Junkers  is reported to have carried out a solo attack on the tank farm, dropping two lb bombs damaging two tanks. But none of the bombs exploded although they cause a major spillage of oil.Mrs Brown said she understood there were plans to remove some tanks to build houses. She said: ldquoBut it takes time for these sites to be decontaminated from their former industrial uses.In , flats built in Joss Street had to be demolished because the site, which had been formerly used as a gas works, hadnrsquot been properly decontaminated.What do you think  Share your views by emailing us at newsdesk@spp-groupSaturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Port of Criomarty Firth to share details of expansion plan
story: DETAILS of the multimillion-pound expansion of the Port of Cromarty Firth will be unveiled to the publicthis week.The time frame behind the portrsquos ongoing pound million transformation, and efforts to grow its cruise ship trade and work within the energy sector, will all be discussed at an exhibition in Invergordon tomorrow.The event, which will run from pm to pm, is part of the portrsquos efforts to provide regular progress updates on how construction of the quayside expansion is going.Work began last month and is expected to run until March next year, ahead of the portrsquos planned involvement with assembling turbines for the Moray East Offshore Windfarm.A spokesman said: ldquoThe port has been ersying its offering over the past few years, to appeal to a wider range of business sectors and ensure we can create jobs and economic opportunities for the Highland region into the future.ldquoThis has included expanding from our traditional support for the North Sea oil and gas sector into renewable energy and cruise tourism.ldquoThe port has established itself as the waterborne tourist gateway to the Highlands. This positioning means that Invergordon receives more cruise passengers than any other port in Scotland, generating over pound million in tourist spend and hundreds of jobs within the wider Highland economy in . This will increase to pound million this year.The expansion was triggered by the successful award of a pound million contract from the Moray East Offshore Windfarm to use the site to assemble its turbines.The exhibition, which will be held at the port offices in Shore Road, will display the construction programme and timings of the expansion project and are welcome.AN experienced solicitor has joined the board of the port.Rhona Harper, who has worked for more than  years as a solicitor, is a procurement law specialist, experienced in developing and implementing innovative public private partnerships.For  years, she was a partner of the Scottish law firm Shepherd and Wedderburn during which team she managed a team of solicitors and support staff and led the firmrsquos Government and Public Sector Group.The board meets regularly to review the PoCFrsquos business and future plans. They are not owners or shareholders but manage the organisation which reinvests all its profits into the development of the Trust Port.Bob Buskie, chief executive of the PoCF, said: ldquoThe port is absolutely thrilled to bring Rhonarsquos vast experience to our board. title: Ross shire pupil wins undisclosed sum from Highland Council after wall debris broke leg at school
story: Max MacPhee, aged seven, was injured by falling debris at Ben Wyvis Primary School in Conon Bridge.He was hospitalised with a broken leg and is now left with one leg cm longer than the other.Highland Council denied liability throughout a civil action but last week backtracked by offering an out-of-court settlement after Digby Brown Solicitors proved they knew of an earlier debris fall one year before Max was injured.While glad to win the case, mum Louise MacPhee , accused the council of acting ldquoshamefully.She said: ldquoItrsquos shocking that Highland Council didnrsquot have the common decency to hold their hands up and just help a little boy who was hurt by their own failings instead of having the audacity to try and blame him.Max was injured in May  when he was then aged five-years-old.He had been leaning on the wall after his morning nursery session when a coping stone detached and struck him on the right leg ndash breaking it just beneath the knee.Max spent two months in recovery most of which was spent using a wheelchair or a walking frame.His bed was placed in the living room as he couldnrsquot walk up the stairs and for the first few weeks of his recovery the youngster also had to be bathed by hand while lying on top of the kitchen counter because he couldnrsquot get in the bath.Louise, a bar maid from Conon Bridge, added: ldquoThe council put us through hell, not to mention wasted public money on legal bills, when they could just have done the right thing from day one.ldquoAt least now they can be held accountable and everyone will know their shameful tactics in blaming a little boy.ldquoIf therersquos any good to come from this then I hope itrsquos that the council give themselves a serious shake and invest in improving the safety of public areas so people arenrsquot hurt in the first place.David McGowan, associate at Digby Brownrsquos Inverness office, led the legal action against Highland Council.He said his investigations found the local authority was alerted to structure concerns at Ben Wyvis Primary when a coping stone fell from the same wall in .But despite this he claimed the council failed to carry out adequate inspections or repair work.Mr McGowan, who helped secure the undisclosed settlement, said: ldquoThis was clearly an accident waiting to happen and itrsquos distressing to consider how much worse Max or anyone  could have been injured.ldquoEvery local authority has a duty of care towards those entering their premises and this is especially important when considering schools and nurseries.ldquoSecuring rightful damages is just one aspect of how we help iniduals - the other is holding defenders accountable to hopefully improve safety standards for all.Asked for comment, a Highland Council spokeswoman said: ldquoIt is the councilrsquos policy not to comment on insurance claims.Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: brexit lib dems shouldn t back returning to eu after departure mp says
story: The Liberal Democrats shouldn’t campaign to take the UK back into the EUthe party fails to stop Brexit, a senior party source has said.The Lib Dem MP said keeping up the party’s campaign to stay in the EU after Brexit would put it at odds with the public mood, and get in the way of addressing other issues facing the UK.Addressing the Scottish Lib Dem conference in Hamilton today, party leader Sir Vince Cable will keep up the pressure for a second EU referendum that could stop Brexit.Mr Cable will pledge to work with a newly-formed group of independent MPs, made up of pro-EU defectors from Labour and the Conservatives, to back a last-ditch Commons bid for a so-called People’s Vote next week.However, one of his MPs told The Scotsman that the campaign for EU membership should be put on hold the day after Brexit,the Lib Dem referendum push fails.“If Brexit does happen, I don’t see that we should automatically and immediately say to people, ‘We need to go back in’,” the source said.“I just don’t think that’s where the country is going to be. Obviously we would argue for the UK to stay close to the EU, and to preserve as many of the protections and benefits it gave us as possible.“But to say on  March, or whenever it is, that our top priority should be rejoining the EU and having that argument all over again - I’m not convinced of that.”The comments hint at the soul-searching that lies ahead for the pro-EU Lib Dems after Brexit, as they try to regroup and recapture their lost support. With the party, now in danger of being eclipsed by the Independent Group set up this week, questions are mounting over whether the Lib Dems have a future as a distinct political brand.Mr Cable has already offered an electoral pact to the -strong breakaway group, in an echo of the Liberal-SDP alliance that eventually led to the formation of the Liberal Democrats.The Scottish Lib Dem MP Christine Jardine has also backed an alliance, but other party sources have been quoted voicing unhappiness at the prospect of a tie-up.A Lib Dem spokesman said “all our efforts are focused on winning” a People’s Vote. “With no majority for any deal and the two tired old parties ided and hopelessly chasing a unicorn Brexit, Liberal Democrats are confident that this mess can be stopped,” he said.In his speech in Hamilton today, Mr Cable will say the Lib Dems have “much in common” with the Independent Group. “For months, I have been speaking with many of these now independent MPs,” he is expected to say. “We cannot let Theresa May or Jeremy Corbyn conspire to run down the clock.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings
